text:
104-116 Sheriff Street, north east corner and Stanton Street, showing P.S. 22.

Board of Education, N.Y.C.

1920.

Sheriff Street, east side, north from Rivington, to and including Stanton Streets, showing the type of tenements which predominate in this area. On the left, at the N.E. corner of Stanton Street, appears P.S. No 22

November 1923.

New York World.

Social Conditions in Manhattan: Open air space in the block bounded by Sheriff, Columbia, Rivington and Stanton Streets. Note the rubbish and debris scattered in the yards.

About 1923.

Gift of New York World.
title: Social conditions in Manhattan - [Open air space in the block bounded by Sheriff, Columbia, Rivington, and Stanton Streets.]

text:
Hamilton Fish Park: Children climbing on iron cage like structures in the south side of the eastern half of this play area. Buildings seen are on the south side of Stanton Street between Willett and Sheriff Streets; the latter appearing on the left.

June 10, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

Hamilton Fish Park: The Stanton Street side of same as viewed from Sheriff Street, showing this recreation area in a transitional phase. The foreground, the eastern half, will be developed as a playground and the new swimming pool will be in the westerly half. The photographer is viewing in a westward and northwestward direction and shows buildings on Pitt Street (in No. 1) and East Houston Street (No. 2). Upon the latter thoroughfare appears a Jewish School and a branch of the New York Public Library.

April 26, 1935.
Views 1 and 2
View 3: September 18, 1935.

P.L. Sperr

View 3: September 18, 1935.

P.L. Sperr

Stanton Street, east from Willett Street (extreme right) showing the southeastern corner of the recently rehabilitated Hamilton Fish Park. Across same appears two buildings housing P.S. No. 22. These bear No. 104 Sheriff Street and are at the N.E. corner of Stanton Street.

June 29, 1938.

P.L. Sperr
